bestBHT.bht: Mark 7:16, not found in all early manuscripts, is often used as a customary way to conclude teachings that may be difficult to understand. It emphasizes the significance of attentive listening and comprehension, calling upon those with receptive ears to truly hear and appreciate the message being conveyed.

Philip Schaff: Mark 7:16 is not found in some early manuscripts. The words were a common close to instruction difficult to understand.
John Gill: If any man have ears to hear, let him hear.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse Mark 7:16, although not found in some early manuscripts, serves as a common close to instruction that may be challenging to comprehend. It emphasizes the importance of truly hearing and understanding the message being conveyed, urging individuals with receptive ears to pay attention and grasp its significance.

Mark 7:16, not present in some early manuscripts, acts as a typical conclusion to difficult teachings. It emphasizes the necessity of actively listening and comprehending the message being imparted. Those with attentive ears are called to truly hear and grasp the significance of the instruction given.

Mark 7:16 serves as a customary conclusion to challenging instructions, stressing the importance of attentive listening and understanding. Although not present in all early manuscripts, it highlights the need for receptive ears to truly hear and comprehend the message being conveyed.
